word_breakdown: Bore = morning, da = good
usage_note: Used as a greeting in the morning; works in both formal and informal situations.
pattern_examples: Bore da / Prynhawn da / Noswaith dda

word_breakdown: Prynhawn = afternoon, da = good
usage_note: Used in the afternoon as a greeting; formal and informal.
pattern_examples: Prynhawn da / Bore da / Noswaith dda

word_breakdown: Noswaith = evening, dda = good (soft mutation of 'da')
usage_note: Used in the evening as a greeting; note the mutation from 'da' to 'dda'.
pattern_examples: Noswaith dda / Bore da / Nos da

word_breakdown: Nos = night, da = good
usage_note: Used when saying good night or before going to sleep.
pattern_examples: Nos da / Noswaith dda / Bore da

word_breakdown: Sut = how, wyt = are (you), ti = you (informal)
usage_note: Informal way to ask someone how they are; use 'Sut ydych chi?' for formal or plural.
pattern_examples: Sut wyt ti? / Sut ydych chi?

word_breakdown: Da = good, iawn = very
usage_note: Means 'very good' or 'well'; common reply to 'How are you?'.
pattern_examples: Da iawn / Iawn / Da

word_breakdown: Diolch = thank you
usage_note: Standard way to say thank you in Welsh; works in all situations.
pattern_examples: Diolch / Diolch yn fawr / Diolch yn fawr iawn

word_breakdown: Croeso = welcome
usage_note: Means 'welcome' or 'you're welcome' in response to thanks.
pattern_examples: Croeso / Dim problem

word_breakdown: Dw i’n = I am, hoffi = like
usage_note: Used to express likes; follow with a noun or activity.
pattern_examples: Dw i’n hoffi coffi / Dw i’n hoffi darllen

example: Dw i ddim yn hoffi te.
word_breakdown: Dw i ddim = I am not, yn hoffi = like
usage_note: Used to express dislikes; follow with a noun or activity.
pattern_examples: Dw i ddim yn hoffi te / Dw i ddim yn hoffi cig

word_breakdown: Ble = where, mae = is
usage_note: Use to ask where something is; add the item after 'Ble mae...'.
pattern_examples: Ble mae’r orsaf? / Ble mae’r tŷ bach?

word_breakdown: Dw i eisiau = I want
usage_note: Common way to express a want; often pronounced 'isho'.
pattern_examples: Dw i eisiau paned / Dw i eisiau bwyd

example: Sori, dw i ddim yn gwybod.
word_breakdown: Dw i ddim = I am not, yn gwybod = know
usage_note: Used when you don’t know something; works in all contexts.
pattern_examples: Dw i ddim yn gwybod / Sori, dw i ddim yn gwybod

word_breakdown: Beth = what, yw = is, dy = your, enw = name, di = you
usage_note: Informal way to ask someone’s name.
pattern_examples: Beth yw dy enw di? / Beth yw eich enw chi?

word_breakdown: Enw = name, fi = me, yw = is, Luke = Luke
usage_note: Use to give your name; replace Luke with your own.
pattern_examples: Enw fi yw Sara / Enw fi yw Rhys

word_breakdown: Braf = nice, cwrdd â = meet, ti = you
usage_note: Informal 'nice to meet you'; for formal use 'Braf cwrdd â chi'.
pattern_examples: Braf cwrdd â ti / Braf cwrdd â chi

front: Dw i’n byw yn Port Talbot
image: media/image/Dw i’n byw yn Port Talbot.png
audio: media/audio/Dw i n byw yn Port T.m4a
example: Dw i’n byw yn Port Talbot.
phonetic: Doo een biw un Port TAL-bot
word_breakdown: Dw i’n = I am, byw = live, yn = in, Port Talbot = Port Talbot
usage_note: States where you live; can be adapted for other locations.
pattern_examples: Dw i’n byw yng Nghaerdydd / Dw i’n byw yn Abertawe

word_breakdown: A = and, ti = you
usage_note: Informal way to say 'and you?' in conversation.
pattern_examples: Dw i’n iawn. A ti? / Da iawn. A ti?

example: Os gwelwch yn dda, gallwch chi helpu?
word_breakdown: Os = if, gwelwch = see, yn dda = good
usage_note: Polite way to say please (formal); use with strangers or in formal settings.
pattern_examples: Os gwelwch yn dda / Os gweli di’n dda

example: Dw i’n dysgu Cymraeg bob dydd.
word_breakdown: Dw i’n = I am, dysgu = learning, Cymraeg = Welsh
usage_note: Use to say you are learning Welsh; good for introducing yourself as a learner.
pattern_examples: Dw i’n dysgu Cymraeg / Dw i’n dysgu ychydig o Gymraeg

audio: media/audio/Dw i n byw yng Nghym.m4a
word_breakdown: Dw i’n = I am, byw = live, yng = in, Cymru = Wales
usage_note: States you live in Wales; 'yng' triggers nasal mutation.
pattern_examples: Dw i’n byw yng Nghymru / Dw i’n byw yn Lloegr

word_breakdown: Wyt = are, ti = you, yn = (present tense marker), siarad = speak, Cymraeg = Welsh
usage_note: Informal way to ask if someone speaks Welsh.
pattern_examples: Wyt ti’n siarad Cymraeg? / Ydych chi’n siarad Cymraeg?

example: Dw i’n dysgu ychydig o Gymraeg.
word_breakdown: Dw i’n = I am, dysgu = learning, ychydig = a little
usage_note: Used to say you are learning a little; can be about Welsh or another subject.
pattern_examples: Dw i’n dysgu ychydig o Gymraeg / Dw i’n dysgu ychydig o Ffrangeg

word_breakdown: Dw i’n = I am, newydd = new/just, dechrau = start
usage_note: Means you have just started something; 'dechrau' soft-mutates to 'ddechrau'.
pattern_examples: Dw i’n newydd ddechrau dysgu / Dw i’n newydd ddechrau gweithio

word_breakdown: Mae’n = it is, bwrw = throwing, glaw = rain
usage_note: Literal meaning 'it is throwing rain'; means 'it’s raining'.
pattern_examples: Mae’n bwrw glaw / Mae’n bwrw eira

word_breakdown: Mae’n = it is, heulog = sunny
usage_note: Describes sunny weather; can be used in small talk.
pattern_examples: Mae’n heulog heddiw / Mae’n braf heddiw

word_breakdown: Dw i’n = I am, oer = cold
usage_note: Used to say you feel cold; common in daily conversation.
pattern_examples: Dw i’n oer heddiw / Mae hi’n oer

word_breakdown: Dw i’n = I am, boeth = hot
usage_note: Used to say you feel hot; common in weather or physical exertion contexts.
pattern_examples: Dw i’n boeth heddiw / Mae hi’n boeth iawn

example: Dw i’n sychedig ar ôl rhedeg.
word_breakdown: Dw i’n = I am, sychedig = thirsty
usage_note: Used to say you are thirsty; common in casual speech.
pattern_examples: Dw i’n sychedig ar ôl rhedeg / Mae syched arna i
